message_1: Let X = {1, 2, 3} have the discrete topology and let Y = {0} have the trivial topology. Suppose f: X → Y is a function. Show that f is continuous.
message_2:
To show that f is continuous, we need to show that the preimage of every open set in Y is open in X.

Since Y has the trivial topology, its open sets are the empty set Ø and Y itself.

Case 1: Consider the open set Ø in Y. The preimage of Ø under f, denoted by f^(-1)(Ø), is also the empty set Ø, since no element in X can be mapped to an element in Ø. Since Ø is an open set in the discrete topology on X, f^(-1)(Ø) is open in X.

Case 2: Consider the open set Y in Y. Since f is a function from X to Y, every element in X must be mapped to an element in Y. Therefore, the preimage of Y under f, denoted by f^(-1)(Y), is the entire set X. Since X is an open set in the discrete topology on X, f^(-1)(Y) is open in X.

In both cases, the preimage of the open sets in Y is open in X. Therefore, the function f is continuous.
